newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Belgrade bourse turnover up in week to June 20.
newsitem.headline: Belgrade bourse turnover up in week to June 20.

text.p: The Belgrade Stock Exchange (BSE) reported on Monday a 15 percent increase in its turnover in the week ending June 20 as investors began to lose interest in giro-money and sought moreety in state T-bills.
Total turnover rose to 40.412 million dinars in 151 transactions from 35.139 million dinars in 144 deals a week ago, the bourse said.
Except for 0.2 million dinars worth of shares, the entire activity was conducted on the primary market.
"Capital has started to fly from risky and expensive giro-money to state T-bills. The state is seen as a more reliable debtor although the interest on its paper is lower," a trader told Reuters.
Traders also said the appearance of state T-bills on May 12, which carry a 4.5 percent in monthly interest, influenced interest rates on other instruments to begin to decline.

"The average cost of borrowing is now ranging between 7.00 and 10.00 percent per month compared to a monthly 12-20 percent several weeks ago and the decline has not resulted from any state administrative measures," the trader said.
Analysts insisted there were hardly any borrowers who could service their debt at enormous monthly interest at a time when official average monthly inflation stood at 0.7 percent.
"If debtors were more reliable, seven percent interest would not be on a monthly but on a quarterly, maybe half-year basis," an analyst said.
Traders said market liquidity was slightly improved with the quantity of funds more or less unchanged. But around one third of 105 Yugoslav banks still faced liquidity problems.
For the week ending June 20, the BSE reported the following details:
* Commercial paper accounted for 141 transactions totalling 25.992 million dinars.
* Treasury bills traded four times for a volume of 0.442 million dinars.
Interest rates on commercial paper and treasury bills ranged between 6.00 and 13.00 percent per month, while maturity stood between seven and 360 days.
* The bourse reported a sale of state T-bills worth 13.5 million dinars.
* There was no trade in the central bank short-term bonds.
* Over-the-counter trade in commercial paper and treasury bills fell to 30.356 million dinars from 36.432 million.
* OTC trade in giro money, with banks trading their surplus liquidity, declined to 25.75 million dinars from 31.1 million. -- Gordana Filipovic, Belgrade newsroom, +381 11 222 4254
